user_message:
<misra_rule>
The target MISRA C 2023 Rule 21.14 is: The Standard Library function memcmp shall not be used to compare null terminated strings.

</misra_rule>
<instruction>
Other agents will judge whether the code follows the MISRA C 2023 guidelines.
They will investigate the code fragments you give.
Your job is to find code fragments in the code that should be investigated to check whether the code follows the MISRA C rule.
</instruction>
<response format>
Provide your answer with these fields.
- suspicious_frags: The list of suspicious code fragments in the code.
It should contain only the code fragments exists in the code. If you do not find any suspicious code fragments, return an empty list for suspicious_frags
- explanation: The explanation of why other code fragments should NOT be investigated.
It is very important to not miss any suspicious code fragments, so please give a sufficient explanation why other code fragments should not be investigated.
DO NOT give any explanation for the selected suspicious code fragments.
</response format>
<target_code>
Here is the code of OS_SocketAddrSetPort_Impl:
```c
int32 OS_SocketAddrSetPort_Impl(OS_SockAddr_t *Addr, uint16 PortNum)
{
    in_port_t               sa_port;
    OS_SockAddr_Accessor_t *Accessor;

    sa_port  = htons(PortNum);
    Accessor = (OS_SockAddr_Accessor_t *)&Addr->AddrData;

    switch (Accessor->sa.sa_family)
    {
        case AF_INET:
            Accessor->sa_in.sin_port = sa_port;
            break;
#ifdef OS_NETWORK_SUPPORTS_IPV6
        case AF_INET6:
            Accessor->sa_in6.sin6_port = sa_port;
            break;
#endif
        default:
            return OS_ERR_BAD_ADDRESS;
    }

    return OS_SUCCESS;
}
```
</target_code>
<additional code>Here are the definitions of symbols that are related to the target function OS_SocketAddrSetPort_Impl:
typedef struct
{
    size_t            ActualLength; /**< @brief Length of the actual address data */
    OS_SockAddrData_t AddrData;     /**< @brief Abstract Address data */
} OS_SockAddr_t
...
typedef union
{
    char               data[OS_SOCKADDR_MAX_LEN];
    struct sockaddr    sa;
    struct sockaddr_in sa_in;
#ifdef OS_NETWORK_SUPPORTS_IPV6
    struct sockaddr_in6 sa_in6;
#endif
} OS_SockAddr_Accessor_t
...
#define OS_ERR_BAD_ADDRESS (-34)
...
#define OS_SUCCESS (0)
...
typedef uint16_t  uint16
...
typedef int32_t   int32
</additional code>
Please find suspicious code fragments in the code and report them. Other agents can not investigate other fragments that you do not report, so it is very important to find all suspicious fragments without missing any. Report the suspicious fragments AS MUCH AS POSSIBLE.
explanation: I inspected the provided function and related definitions for any use of memcmp or any other byte-wise comparison functions used to compare null-terminated strings (e.g., memcmp, strcmp, strncmp). None are present. The function only: converts a numeric port with htons, casts the Addr->AddrData into an accessor union, switches on sa_family, and assigns numeric port fields (sin_port or sin6_port). The union contains a char data[] member but it is not used for any string comparison in the shown code. No calls to memcmp (or other string-comparison functions) occur in the target function or the supplied related definitions, so there are no code fragments that should be investigated for Rule 21.14 in the provided snippets.
